Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a lekanis lid; interior glazed black; exterior: two dilute bands above frieze with black-figure decoration, confronted panther and goat (of panther, head, neck, shoulders and part of forelegs remain, with added red spots on neck and chest; of the grazing goat, part of head, neck and horn remain; red on ear).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p. 340)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 123, no. 347.5, pl. XXXVIII)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 231, no. 166)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.2093)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5963 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
